text: 5k is definitely a lot, the article that I'm trying to revamp is a guide to troubleshoot a bunch of technical issues with our competitor's product, so it all currently lives on one page. It might be better to make it a series, but I am also open to different UX ideas to keep it all together but break it up. Perhaps videos would help.

text:
I think if you make the story compelling from top to bottom, 5k on one page isn't much.

Here's a recent almost 5k guide my team just did for a client (it's not too technical though, but maybe the outlining and flow could help):

<https://gethoneycart.com/post-covid-profits-with-catering-automation/|https://gethoneycart.com/post-covid-profits-with-catering-automation/>

attachments.title: Post-COVID Profits: 5 Experts Share How Caterers Can Bounce Back with Over
attachments.text: Five industry experts share insights for caterers to bounce back stronger in the new normal. Also, see how catering automation saves you thousands by eliminating manual processes.

text:
Hey everyone, curious to hear about what everyone's split is between blog and other content — what are your responsibilities that extend beyond all things blog? Our company has chosen to pivot and put more content resourcing towards our 'money pages', with content working more closely with design / UX / product.

*What kind of role do you think the content team plays here?* Keen to hear about all thoughts / feelings!

elements.text: Hey everyone, curious to hear about what everyone's split is between blog and other content — what are your responsibilities that extend beyond all things blog? Our company has chosen to pivot and put more content resourcing towards our 'money pages', with content working more closely with design / UX / product.
What kind of role do you think the content team plays here?
Keen to hear about all thoughts / feelings!

text: Who (design/ux/content/product) is coming up with the topics of the ‘money pages’ and the words/copy that goes on those pages?

elements.text: Who (design/ux/content/product) is coming up with the topics of the ‘money pages’ and the words/copy that goes on those pages?

text: (I’m assuming ‘money pages’ is ‘non-blog content that’s targeting a specific keyword with the goal of being top of funnel to attract visitors and convert them towards a revenue producing funnel, e.g., software, services, consulting’, ya?)

elements.text: (I’m assuming ‘money pages’ is ‘non-blog content that’s targeting a specific keyword with the goal of being top of funnel to attract visitors and convert them towards a revenue producing funnel, e.g., software, services, consulting’, ya?)

text: Hey Kai! I'm more talking about pages that are targeting commercial intent keywords, i.e. if a user searches 'accounting courses', they'll land on a commercial page that has a collection of accounting courses they can then find out more about (we're a B2C edu marketplace).

elements.text: Hey Kai! I'm more talking about pages that are targeting commercial intent keywords, i.e. if a user searches 'accounting courses', they'll land on a commercial page that has a collection of accounting courses they can then find out more about (we're a B2C edu marketplace).

text:
<@U016CGRMRAR> regarding your question on “_what role does the content team play_?”, I think it’s a bit arbitrary here. You could have a copywriter completely outside of marketing team who is producing these - but they still need to be informational and optimized for search.

Or you could utilize the same writer who is doing all blog content - but they still need to meet the brand’s product and conversion requirements even if they make a great informational page.

So _which_ team does it is arbitrary to me so long as all stakeholders agree that the pages have to meet those requirements to succeed.

Then the question becomes about resourcing: making sure organization is putting time and budget to both content tracks, and staffing appropriately.

If you find that an editorial team is suddenly being asked to own all conversion content, I think that is a natural point to request the staff resources to tackle both sets of goals. It will also help to show that having writers dedicated to different page types and content efforts will help everyone specialize and not jump around randomly across projects.

At the end of the day, it’s all content, but they are two separate content programs and the conversion content is likely impacting 100% of incoming leads, so I’d be worried if the organization was treating it like a maintenance project that content team can deal with. But the positive spin is that it’s a chance for your team to get closer to revenue than editorial would allow. So you should be able to demonstrate growth/ROI/success easier.
